meanings.definition: to be or become weak or feeble
meanings.sent1: After being sick for a week, he began to languish in bed, unable to move.
meanings.sent2: The plant will languish if it doesn't get enough sunlight and water.
meanings.sent3: The puppy pretended to languish dramatically when it didn't get a treat.
meanings.sent4: Her dreams of becoming a dancer started to languish as she grew older.
meanings.sent5: The old house continued to languish, showing signs of neglect and decay.

meanings.definition: to suffer from being forced to remain in an unpleasant place or situation
meanings.sent1: The prisoners languish in their cells, longing for freedom.
meanings.sent2: She had to languish in the long queue at the post office.
meanings.sent3: The cat seemed to languish in the boring routine of eating and sleeping.
meanings.sent4: The students began to languish in the hot classroom during the power outage.
meanings.sent5: The workers had to languish in the noisy construction site all day.

meanings.definition: to lose or lack vitality; grow weak
meanings.sent1: Without proper care, the flowers will languish and wilt.
meanings.sent2: The team started to languish after their star player got injured.
meanings.sent3: The neglected garden began to languish, overrun by weeds.
meanings.sent4: His enthusiasm for the project began to languish as the deadlines approached.
meanings.sent5: The once vibrant neighborhood began to languish as businesses closed down.
